member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EnvironmentMapEffect.EnvironmentMapAmount
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of the environment map RGB that will be blended over the base texture. Range 0 to 1, default 1. If set to zero, the RGB channels of the environment map will completely ignored (but the environment map alpha may still be visible if EnvironmentMapSpecular is greater than zero).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EnvironmentMapEffect.EnvironmentMapSpecular
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of the environment map alpha channel that will be added to the base texture. Range 0 to 1, default 0. This can be used to implement cheap specular lighting, by encoding one or more specular highlight patterns into the environment map alpha channel, then setting EnvironmentMapSpecular to the desired specular light color.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EnvironmentMapEffect.FresnelFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Fresnel factor used for the environment map blending. Higher values make the environment map only visible around the silhouette edges of the object, while lower values make it visible everywhere. Setting this property to 0 disables Fresnel entirely, making the environment map equally visible regardless of view angle. The default is 1. Fresnel only affects the environment map RGB (the intensity of which is controlled by EnvironmentMapAmount). The alpha contribution (controlled by EnvironmentMapSpecular) is not affected by the Fresnel setting.

member.summary: This effect requires lighting, so we explicitly implement IEffectLights.LightingEnabled, and do not allow turning it off.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend
member.summary: Defines a blend mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.One
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by {1, 1, 1, 1}.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.Zero
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by {0, 0, 0, 0}.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.SourceColor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the source color. {Rs, Gs, Bs, As}, where Rs, Gs, Bs, As are color source values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseSourceColor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of the source color. {1 Rs, 1 Gs, 1 Bs, 1 As}, where Rs, Gs, Bs, As are color source values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.SourceAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the alpha value of the source. {As, As, As, As}, where As is the source alpha value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseSourceAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of the alpha value of the source. {1 As, 1 As, 1 As, 1 As}, where As is the source alpha value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.DestinationColor
member.summary: Each component color is multiplied by the destination color. {Rd, Gd, Bd, Ad}, where Rd, Gd, Bd, Ad are color destination values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseDestinationColor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inversed destination color. {1 Rd, 1 Gd, 1 Bd, 1 Ad}, where Rd, Gd, Bd, Ad are color destination values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.DestinationAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the alpha value of the destination. {Ad, Ad, Ad, Ad}, where Ad is the destination alpha value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseDestinationAlpha

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexBuffer.GetData``1(System.Int32,``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the vertex data froom this VertexBuffer.
member.typeparam: The struct you want to fill.
member.param: The offset to the first element in the vertex buffer in bytes.
An array of T's to be filled.
The index to start filling the data array.
The number of T's to get.
The size of how a vertex buffer element should be interpreted.
member.remarks: Note that this pulls data from VRAM into main memory and because of that is a very expensive operation. It is often a better idea to keep a copy of the data in main memory.

remarks.p: Using this operation it is easy to get certain vertex elements from a VertexBuffer.

For example to get the texture coordinates from a VertexBuffer of you can call GetData(4 * 3, data, elementCount, 20). 'data'should be an array of in this example. The offsetInBytes is the number of bytes taken up by the of the vertex. For vertexStride we pass the size of a .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexBuffer.SetData``1(System.Int32,``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the vertex buffer data, specifying the index at which to start copying from the source data array, the number of elements to copy from the source data array, and how far apart elements from the source data array should be when they are copied into the vertex buffer.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in the data array.
member.param: Offset in bytes from the beginning of the vertex buffer to the start of the copied data.
Data array.
Index at which to start copying from . Must be within the array bounds.
Number of elements to copy from . The combination of and must be within the array bounds.

Specifies how far apart, in bytes, elements from should be when they are copied into the vertex buffer. In almost all cases this should be sizeof(T), to create a tightly-packed vertex buffer. If you specify sizeof(T), elements from will be copied into the vertex buffer with no padding between each element. If you specify a value greater than sizeof(T), elements from will be copied into the vertex buffer with padding between each element. If you specify 0 for this parameter, it will be treated as if you had specified sizeof(T). With the exception of 0, you must specify a value greater than or equal to sizeof(T).
member.remarks: If you provide a byte[] in the parameter, then you should almost certainly set to 1, to avoid leaving any padding between the byte values when they are copied into the vertex buffer.

member.summary: Sets the vertex buffer data, specifying the index at which to start copying from the source data array, and the number of elements to copy from the source data array. This is the same as calling with offsetInBytes equal to 0, and vertexStride equal to sizeof(T).
member.typeparam: Type of elements in the data array.
member.param: Data array.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.UseHalfPixelOffset
member.summary: Indicates if DX9 style pixel addressing or current standard pixel addressing should be used. This flag is set to false by default. If `UseHalfPixelOffset` is `true` you have to add half-pixel offset to a Projection matrix. See also .
member.remarks: XNA uses DirectX9 for its graphics. DirectX9 interprets UV coordinates differently from other graphics API's. This is typically referred to as the half-pixel offset. MonoGame replicates XNA behavior if this flag is set to true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode
member.summary: Defines sprite sort rendering options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.Deferred
member.summary: All sprites are drawing when invokes, in order of draw call sequence. Depth is ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.Immediate
member.summary: Each sprite is drawing at individual draw call, instead of . Depth is ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.Texture
member.summary: Same as , except sprites are sorted by texture prior to drawing. Depth is ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.BackToFront
member.summary: Same as , except sprites are sorted by depth in back-to-front order prior to drawing. An unstable sort is used, which means sprites with equal depth may not have their order preserved.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.FrontToBack
member.summary: Same as , except sprites are sorted by depth in front-to-back order prior to drawing. An unstable sort is used, which means sprites with equal depth may not have their order preserved.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat
member.summary: Defines types of surface formats.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Color
member.summary: Unsigned 32-bit ARGB pixel format for store 8 bits per channel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr565
member.summary: Unsigned 16-bit BGR pixel format for store 5 bits for blue, 6 bits for green, and 5 bits for red.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgra5551
member.summary: Unsigned 16-bit BGRA pixel format where 5 bits reserved for each color and last bit is reserved for alpha.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgra4444
member.summary: Unsigned 16-bit BGRA pixel format for store 4 bits per channel.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture.SortingKey
member.summary: Gets a unique identifier of this texture for sorting purposes.

remarks.para: For example, this value is used by when drawing with .
The value is an implementation detail and may change between application launches or MonoGame versions. It is only guaranteed to stay consistent during application lifetime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.FromStream(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Creates a from a stream, supported formats bmp, gif, jpg, png, tif and dds (only for simple textures). May work with other formats, but will not work with tga files.
member.param: The graphics device to use to create the texture.
The stream from which to read the image data.
member.returns: The created from the image stream.
member.remarks: Note that different image decoders may generate slight differences between platforms, but perceptually the images should be identical. This call does not premultiply the image alpha, but areas of zero alpha will result in black color data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Viewport.Project(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix)
member.summary: Projects a from model space into screen space. The source point is transformed from model space to world space by the world matrix, then from world space to view space by the view matrix, and finally from view space to screen space by the projection matrix.
member.param: The to project.
The projection .
The view .
The world .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Viewport.Unproject(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix)
member.summary: Unprojects a from screen space into model space. The source point is transformed from screen space to view space by the inverse of the projection matrix, then from view space to world space by the inverse of the view matrix, and finally from world space to model space by the inverse of the world matrix. Note source.Z must be less than or equal to MaxDepth.
member.param: The to unproject.
The projection .
The view .
The world .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsNonPowerOfTwo
member.summary: Whether the device fully supports non power-of-two textures, including mip maps and wrap modes other than CLAMP_TO_EDGE

member.summary: Whether the device supports anisotropic texture filtering

member.summary: Gets the support for DXT1

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsS3tc
member.summary: Gets the support for S3TC (DXT1, DXT3, DXT5)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsPvrtc
member.summary: Gets the support for PVRTC

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsEtc1
member.summary: Gets the support for ETC1

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsEtc2
member.summary: Gets the support for ETC2

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsAtitc
member.summary: Gets the support for ATITC

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsSRgb
member.summary: True, if sRGB is supported. On Direct3D platforms, this is always true. On OpenGL platforms, it is true if both framebuffer sRGB and texture sRGB are supported.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsFloatTextures
member.summary: True, if the underlying platform supports floating point textures. For Direct3D platforms this is always true. For OpenGL Desktop platforms it is always true. For OpenGL Mobile platforms it requires `GL_EXT_color_buffer_float`. If the requested format is not supported an NotSupportedException will be thrown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.SupportsHalfFloatTextures
member.summary: True, if the underlying platform supports half floating point textures. For Direct3D platforms this is always true. For OpenGL Desktop platforms it is always true. For OpenGL Mobile platforms it requires `GL_EXT_color_buffer_half_float`. If the requested format is not supported an NotSupportedException will be thrown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Platform.Graphics.GraphicsCapabilities.MaxTextureAnisotropy
member.summary: Gets the max texture anisotropy. This value typically lies between 0 and 16, where 0 means anisotropic filtering is not supported.
